name: You've Been Angloed Quiz | Mixed UK | 10 Questions

questions.text: The new 10 pound note came into circulation in November 2000. Who is on the back of this note? (No looking now!)
questions.explanation:
Charles Darwin.

	Charles Dickens is depicted on the 'old' 10 pound note, which is still in circulation alongside the new note.

questions.text: There are four Tate Galleries. Two are in London, but where are the other two?
questions.explanation:
Liverpool & St. Ives

	The gallery in Millbank (London) was founded in 1897, Liverpool (1988), St Ives (1993) and Bankside (London) in 2000.

questions.text: With which TV program would you associate DS Chisholm and the Winchester Club?
questions.explanation:
Minder.

	'Minder' began in 1979 and starred George Cole as 'Arfer' Daley and Dennis Waterman as Terry McCann.

questions.text: According to the Highway Code, what should you not do between 11.30pm and 7am?
options: Leave your vehicle in the pub car park
Leave interior lights on whilst driving a vehicle
Assist in the teaching of a learner driver
questions.explanation:
Sound your horn.

	Unless another vehicle poses a danger, you should not sound your horn at this time in a built up area.

questions.text:
The Opel Kadett was the year's most desirable car; Sid Vicious died; 'I Don't Like Mondays' was the fourth best selling single. 
What year was that?
Which of the following were NOT born in the UK?
questions.explanation:
Duke of Edinburgh.

	The Duke of Edinburgh was born in Corfu, Gustav Holst (composer) was born in Cheltenham and Lennox Lewis (boxer) was born in London but moved to Canada at the age of twelve.

questions.text: Who fought the Cod Wars with Britain?
questions.explanation:
Iceland.

	Between 1952 and 1976, four cod wars were fought.

questions.text: Apart from on a Sunday, it is legal in York to shoot a Scotsman with what?
options: None of these - It's illegal to shoot anyone
questions.explanation:
Bow and Arrow.

	However only if you spot him within the city walls after dark. In Hereford you can shoot a Welsh person in broad daylight, but only on Sunday, with a longbow, in the Cathedral Close, too.

Edwin Budding.

	It was invented in 1830 by Budding who came from Stroud, Gloucestershire.

Westminster Abbey.

	All but two of the British monarchs have been crowned at Westminster Abbey since the coronation of William, Duke of Normandy, on Christmas Day in 1066.
